loans.name: Apolinar

texts.en:
Being an experienced dairy farmer, Apolinar knows how increasing LP gas prices and chemical fertilizers can disproportionately reduce his income. He decided to acquire a Sistema Biobolsa biodigester in order to free himself from this financial burden and to become his own energy and fertilizer supplier. 

He can do this by inputting his cows' manure in the biodigester, where bacteria will transform it into renewable energy and nutrient-rich fertilizer. Apolinar will use the biogas to cook and heat water, displacing wood and fossil-fuel-based LP gas in the house and kitchen, while replacing the chemical fertilizer by the organic one, nourishing the soils in a sustainable manner and increasing his crops' yield. 

He looks forward to saving money, improving his productivity and living in a cleaner, more comfortable environment. As he starts saving money, he plans to improve the infrastructure on his farm to widen his cows' corral.

This loan represents 20% of the full cost of the biodigester. The remaining part is being covered by a government subsidy.

loans.use: to invest in a 16 m3 waste-to-energy biodigester.

loans.name: Husniyah

texts.en:
Husniyah is a 23-years-old married lady from Tubas, a village near Nablus city.   She lives with her husband and two kids; a son and a daughter. Her husband has a grocery store in the village. Husniyah helps her husband sometimes.
 
Husniyah took a USD loan from FATEN.   This loan will help her and her husband to buy more grocery products for the store to resell. This will improve sales and also their income. 
Husniyah appears in the photo while she was in the grocery store

loans.use: to buy more grocery products for the store to resell.

loans.name: Bebeliz

texts.en:
This is Bebeliz. She is 49 years old, married to Julieto, and they have two kids. Today they reside in Pasay City, Philippines. They would do anything for their children.

Bebeliz runs a small egg store. She also has a tailoring business, which is consolidated to earn an income that suffices the basic needs of their family. 

She wants to broaden her enterprise. And she knows that she's seeking help from the right people. She would like to take out a loan worth PHP 10,000 to pay for more supplies of organic eggs to sell in her stall. If her business develops, it would be a better opportunity and certainly an open door to earning, then eventually she would go from the bottom up. 

What she just dreams, just like the other people, is to have her own house and car. But most importantly, she wishes her family will always stay in good health and condition. 

She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more supplies of eggs to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Hoy

texts.en:
Hoy, 38, is a married mother living with her four children in a rural village of the Kratie district of Kratie province, Cambodia. She earns a living through farming rice and catching fish and she has been in this business for 20 years, earning about 35,00KHR per day. 

Hoy has been a member of VisionFund for three cycles already and she completely repaid the past loans, which have helped her relieve her family’s financial burden and support her business. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for supporting her rice farming business. She hopes to grow good quality crops so as to better support her family.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers for supporting her rice farming business

loans.name: Vicente Javier

texts.es: Luego de varios años como empleado en varias empresas de productos cárnicos  y quedar desempleado, Vicente de 45 años, decidió que contaba con la suficiente experiencia y el ánimo requerido para independizarse e iniciar como microempresario; invirtió los dineros de su liquidación en su idea de negocio;  fabricación de butifarras, chorizos, salchichas, jamones, perniles y demás,  actividad con la que ha logrado un sustento económico digno y creciente para su familia. Vicente trabaja desde su hogar en el horario de 5:00 a.m. a 8:00 p.m. en la venta de sus productos  a  vecinos familiares y amigos que integran su clientela, sin embargo no puede competir con los costos de las grandes empresas que lideran esta actividad, por lo que desea realizar una inversión para adquirir sus materias primas e insumos al por mayor, obtener menores costos y poder ofrecer mejores precios a sus clientes; esta estrategia planea financiarla con su primer CrediKiva al que está aplicando con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. Su meta a futuro es tener un punto de venta en un centro comercial donde transitan millares de apresurados habitantes, que se constituyen en mercados muy atractivos para este tipo de negocio.
texts.en:
After several years working as an employee in a variety of meat product businesses and ending up unemployed, Vicente, 45, decided he had enough experience and the requisite energy to go out on his own as a micro-entrepreneur.  He invested his settlement money in his business concept: making Catalan sausage, chorizo, sausage, ham, legs, and other products.  He has earned a decent living and growth for his family with this work.

Vicente works from home from 5 a.m. until 8 p.m.  He sells his products to neighbors, family members, and friends, all of whom make up his clientele.  He can't compete with the large businesses that are leaders in this work, however, so he wants to make an investment to acquire his ingredients and supplies wholesale, get better prices, and be able to sell to his customers at a better price.  He plans to finance this strategy with his first Kiva loan, which he's requesting from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.

His goal for the future is to have a sales space in a shopping center where the thousands of residents rushing by will constitute a very attractive market for this type of business.

loans.use: to buy his ingredients and supplies wholesale at a lower cost so he can sell to his customers at a better price

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel has decided to purchase a large Sistema Biobolsa biodigester to provide his household and farm with renewable energy and to nourish the soil of his fields with nutrient-rich organic fertilizer. He wants to respect the natural cycle of his farm, transforming what he used to consider waste into two precious resources: biogas and organic fertilizer. 

As the biodigester starts working, Manuel will be able to progressively replace the use of expensive and unsustainable gas and chemical fertilizers. His wife will start cooking with biogas instead of wood, eliminating the toxic smoke inhaled from her kitchen and significantly improving her quality of life. 

Manuel sees the biodigester as a logical step toward improved productivity and a higher living standard. He looks forward to taking full advantage of the system and to saving money.

This loan represents 20 per cent of the full cost of the biodigester. The remaining part is being covered by a government subsidy.

loans.use: to invest in a waste-to-energy biodigester (with a 30 cubic meter capacity).

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma has five children. She is from Plaridel and married. Gemma is a diligent and determined mother when it comes to the welfare of her children. For a living, Gemma earns by making snacks that she sells herself and also sells on consignment in shops and cafes. 

She decided to expand her business after learning that she could obtain financial assistance through PMPC. Consequently, she has requested a 7,000 PHP loan to buy additional ingredients to increase production. Her goal is to be able to display her snacks in every shop and place to eat in the area.

 With the help and support of her children, Gemma smiles at the thought of completing her house and living a happy and healthy life.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients to increase production.

loans.name: T´mixe Group

texts.es:
T´Mixe significa pozo en lengua mazahua. Las integrantes decidieron usar ese nombre ya que representa el lugar de donde obtienen el agua que es fundamental para sus hogares. Ellas son personas muy trabajadoras, viven en una comunidad muy tranquila donde gran parte de la población se dedica a criar animales y a cultivar maíz. A pesar de que el nivel de estudios promedio no es muy elevado, los habitantes demuestran una amabilidad y respeto significativos hacia sus semejantes.
 Dentro de su grupo, a Victoria le llaman de cariño Viki, ella es reservada y tranquila, pero con un gran espíritu emprendedor. Tiene 26 años de edad y está casada con Macario quien trabaja como taxista, juntos formaron una familia con tres niños, sus gemelos ya se encuentran estudiando la educación primaria.
 Hace 4 años Viki abrió una paletería,"La iniciamos porque mi esposo estuvo en EE.UU. y con el dinero que mandaba construimos tres locales. Todos estaban en renta, uno de ellos se lo rentábamos a nuestro cuñado quien tenía la paletería, pero cierto día se fue y dejó todo" comento Viki.
 Así que Viki no desaprovechó la oportunidad y dio continuidad al negocio. Con sus ahorros compró algunos litros de helados y paletas. La actividad ha marchado bien y ahora también vende congeladas y yoghurt congelado que los clientes han solicitado. Con el nuevo préstamo, Viki podrá abastecer el local con más helado, paletas y yoghurt. En la época de calor, las ventas mejoran, pero en invierno cuando el sol no aparece, el negocio está prácticamente muerto.
 "Uno de mis sueños es aprender a preparar el helado yo misma para dejar de comprar" comentó Viki aunque sabe que para lograrlo necesitará maquinaria especial, pero esta segura de que algún día llegará a tenerlas.
  Las demás integrantes del grupo son Juana, quien invertirá en un taxi, Maria Luciana, en su tienda de abarrotes, Leticia, Victoria y María Albina, en borregos.

*La fotografía fue tomada en las escaleras debajo debajo del kiosco. En la imagen se pueden apreciar algunos bordados que las integrantes también elaboran para obtener un ingreso extra, Viki es quien tiene el poncho de color azul*
texts.en:
T´Mixe means well in the Mazahua langauge. The members decided to use this name because it represented the place where they get the water that is fundamental for their homes. They are very hard-working people, they live in a very peaceful community where a large part of the population works raising animals and growing corn. Despite the not-very-high average education level, the inhabitants show a lot of warmth and respect to each other.

Within her group, Victoria is lovingly called Viki. She is reserved and peaceful, but with a great enterprising spirit. She is 29 years old and is married to Macario who works as a taxi driver. Together they have a family with three children; their twins are already in primary school. 

Four years ago, Viki opened a popscicle store, "we began because my husband had to be in the US and with the money that he sent, we built three locations. All of them are being rented. We rent one of them to our brother-in-law who had the popscicle place but one day he left and left everything." So, Viki didn't let the opportunity pass her by and it gave her business continuity. With her savings, she purchased some liters of ice cream and popsicles. The work has been going well and now she also sells frozen things, and frozen yogurt is what the customers have requested. With the new loan, Viki will be able to stock her business with more ice cream, popsicles and yogurt. In the hot season, the sales improve, but in the winter when the sun doesn't come out, the business is practically dead.

"One of my dreams is to learn to make ice cream myself to stop buying it," said Viki although she knows that to make it, she will need a special machine, but she is sure that one day she will manage to surely have it.

*The other group members are Juana, who will invest in a taxi, Maria Luciana in her grocery store, and Leticia, Victoria dn María Albina in sheep.*

*The photo was taken on the stairs below the kiosk. In picture, you can see some embroidery that the members make to get extra income. Viki is the one in the blue poncho.*

loans.use: to purchase ice cream, popsicles, yogurt, etc.

location.town: San Lucas, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Ocotepec Group

texts.es:
Un grupo que lleva el nombre de Ocotepec está integrado por personas alegres, en especial Don Fausto quien es el representante. Él es muy trabajador, su familia la conforma la señora María Guadalupe y sus cinco hijos de los cuales ya solo uno depende de la pareja.
   Don Fausto, además de ser un buen campesino, maneja una pequeña tienda de abarrotes desde hace diez años, actividad que emprendió porque siempre había sido una de sus metas. “Desde que inicié a construir mi casa también construí un local donde pudiera estar mi tienda de abarrotes” comentó. Su primera inversión fue posible gracias a sus ahorros y desde el principio buscó ofrecer una gran variedad de productos sobre todo refrescos, dulces y productos enlatados. Hasta ahora el negocio ha tenido éxito, pero la única dificultad es el trasporte; cada ocho días Fausto viaja al municipio para surtirse pero al no tener un vehículo personal el costo del taxi es muy elevado, sin embargo entre sus nuevas metas está el conseguir un automóvil para cubrir esa necesidad.
   Don Fausto, al igual que todo el grupo Ocotepec está muy agradecido porque con su préstamo podrá comprar todo tipo de mercancía como dulces, productos enlatados, refrescos, leche, pan, huevo y azúcar. Él tiene el firme propósito de hacer crecer su tienda para elevar sus ventas, mejorar sus ganancias y como consecuencia, poder apoyar a su hijo para que termine una carrera profesional y tenga una mejor calidad de vida.
   Los demás integrantes del grupo son Elizabeth quien invertirá en su papelería; Olga, en tienda de abarrotes; María Guadalupe, en pollos y Rosa, en ropa. 

* La fotografía fue tomada a un lado de la iglesia del municipio, Don Fausto es el único hombre en el grupo*
texts.en:
The members of the Ocotepec group are all happy people, particularly Fausto, who is the group's representative. He is very hard-working, and has a wife, María Guadalupe, and five children, of whom only one is still dependent. 

Fausto, as well as being a good farmer, has managed a small grocery store for ten years, something which he began as it had always been one of his goals. "When I started building my house, I also built a place for my grocery store" he says. He used his savings to make his first investment, and has always tried to offer a wide variety of items, particularly drinks, sweets, and canned products. His business has been successful so far, and his only problem is transport: every eight days, Fausto goes to the town to replenish stocks, but, because he has no vehicle of his own, the cost of a taxi is very high. However, one of his new goals is to get a car. 

Fausto, along with the other members of the Ocotepec group, is very grateful for the loan, which he will use to buy a wide range of stock items, such as sweets, canned products, drinks, milk, bread, eggs and sugar. He is determined to make his store grow, so that he can increase his sales, improve his earnings, and support his son so that he can study for a professional career and will have a better quality of life.

The other members of the group are Elizabeth, who will invest in her stationery store; Olga, in her grocery store; María Guadalupe, in chickens, and Rosa, in clothing. 

*The photograph was taken near a church in the town. Fausto is the only man in the group.*

loans.use: to buy sweets, canned goods, drinks, milk, bread, eggs, sugar, etc.

location.town: SAN LUCAS OCOTEPEC, SAN FELIPE DEL PROGRESO

loans.name: Mujeres Campesinas Group

texts.es:
El Estado de México se caracteriza por tener comunidades muy tranquilas, llenas de vegetación y habitadas por personas muy trabajadoras. La mayoría  de la población se dedica a al cultivo de maíz y la cría de animales como borregos, becerros, gallinas, etc. Mujeres Campesinas es un grupo formado dentro de la región de raíces mazahuas donde se conservan la lengua materna, las tradiciones y las fiestas. Las integrantes se conocen desde niñas y el lazo de amistad que las une es muy fuerte.
   María Guadalupe es conocida en su como Lupe, ella formó una familia con Don José Guadalupe: tuvieron 11 hijos de los cuales ya solo cuatro dependen de la pareja. 
   Lupe ha dedicado 25 años de su vida a la cría de distintos animales, inició porque en su comunidad es muy sencillo realizar esta actividad. "Pude ayudar con los gastos del hogar que eran muchos cuando mis hijos eran pequeños, además podía estar con ellos todo el tiempo" refiere Doña Lupe. La meta que tiene por delante es obtener  mejores ganancias, por eso además de alimentar a los animales en el campo también les da alimento especial. Pretende emplear el préstamo en la compra de cerdos ya que, con esa ayuda, será capaz de retomar la crianza de estos animales.
   Ella se muestra muy agradecida porque sus hijos han podido seguir estudiando, puesto que sin el apoyo del crédito quizás sus hijos hubieran abandonado la escuela por falta de recursos. La única meta de Doña Lupe es hacer crecer el negocio para que sus hijos puedan desarrollarse profesionalmente. 
   Las demás integrantes son Ma. Francisca, Ma. Asunción, María, Gregoria, Guadalupe, Leticia y Epifania quienes invertirán en pollos y borregos. Aparte de que todas son especialistas en bordados como manteles, servilletas etc.

* La fotografía fue tomada en las escaleras del quiosco municipal, Ma. Guadalupe es quien porta el reboso y suéter blanco*
texts.en:
Mexico is a country full of quiet communities, with abundant vegetation, inhabited by hardworking people, most of them earning a living growing corn and raising animals such as lambs, young bulls, hens, etc. 

Mujeres Campesinas is a group formed within the region of Mazahua origins, where they keep their native language, traditions and festivals. The members  have known each other since childhood and are united by a strong friendship.

Maria Guadalupe, known as Lupe, formed a family with Jose Guadalupe. They have eleven children, and four of them are still dependent on their parents. 

She has raised animals for twenty five years, and chose to do it because in her community this is very simple work. "I was able to help with the household expenses, there were many when the children were young", she comments, "plus I could stay close to them all the time".

Looking to increase her profits, she is feeding the animals special feed in addition to the grazing. She will use the loan to buy pigs and begin to raise them again.

She is very grateful that her children have been able to continue with school, because without the loan assistance her children would possibly have  had to stop studying due to lack of resources. The single goal for Lupe is to expand her business and allow the children to become professionals.

The rest of the group members include Maria Francisca, Maria Asuncion, Maria, Gregoria, Guadalupe, Leticia y Epifania. They will invest in chickens and sheep. Additionally, they all specialize in embroidery work including tablecloths, napkins and more.

The photo above was taken on the steps of the municipal pavilion. Maria Guadalupe is wearing a rebozo [shawl] and sweater.





.

loans.use: To buy piglets.

location.town: Dios Padre, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. Recently, she had a loan worth PHP 20,000 which she had used for her direct-selling business within their vicinity. Actually, she sustains all her needs through her business while ably helping her family at the same time. This is why she would like to give her gratitude to those who lent her assistance previously. 

To improve sales, Vivian would like to apply for a new loan to purchase additional products like accessories to sell. With PHP 30,000, she can certainly improve her livelihood and eventually grow with the grace of God. For now, it is her desire to have people like you who will assist her in her prospects. 

In the future, Vivian hopes to give her family a more favorable kind of living and simultaneously improve her inventory. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like accessories to sell

loans.name: April

texts.en:
April is 39 years old and has four children. She is married and has four children who are in school.

April is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. April requested a PHP 9,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her livestock.

She has been raising livestock for two years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain this.

In the future, April would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her livestock.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy-and-sell vegetable business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock of vegetables to sell for her buy-and-sell vegetable business.

Rebecca has been in this business for seven years. She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses. 

Rebecca has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Anamie

texts.en:
Anamie is 52 years old and married with seven children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur.

Anamie has a charcoal-retailing business in the Philippines. Anamie requested a PHP 13,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy additional stocks of charcoal to sell.

Anamie has been in this business for two years. She wants to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Jeronima

texts.en:
Jeronima is 47 years old and married with two children.

Jeronima works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell like canned goods, milk, drinks, coffee, etc.

Jeronima has borrowed and paid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from food vending.

Jeronima aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell, like canned goods, milk, drinks, coffee, etc.

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with six children, three of whom are in school.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

She supplements this income with earnings from her general store. She successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Leonila dreams that one day she will be able to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college

loans.use: to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en:
Jonalyn is a married woman with eight children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Jonalyn is 41 years old and has two children who are in school.

Jonalyn has a rice retailing business in the Philippines. Jonalyn requested a PHP 24,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy additional stocks of rice to sell.

Jonalyn has been in this business for four years. In the future, Jonalyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en: Mary Grace is 46 years old, married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. For three years, she has run a general store in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from rice farming. Mary Grace requested a 9000 PHP loan through Kiva's partner, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF), to purchase more grocery items to sell like canned goods, noodles, spices, milk, coffee, drinks, etc. Mary Grace has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She aspires to expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in her store

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Mila, one of Ruma’s agents. Mila lives in Majalengka, a regency in West Java, located about 5 hour’s drive from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. She is happily married. Together with her husband, they have one cute son. Mila owns a stall that sells mobile airtime credits for her community. She joined Ruma almost one year ago. She knew Ruma from Ruma’s sales executive that came to her stall. 

As the business grows, Mila is hoping to get a working capital loan from Kiva. She will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits to her community. Having known about the importance, your loan will be very useful to help Mila improve her business and accordingly, her community, which needs access to such services. Mila's goal towards Ruma in the nearly future is to serve an e-commerce business for her community. This is a recent product from Ruma called Mapan, for people in lower communities, so her community can easily have better products with better prices. As seen in the photo, Mila is the one who is sitting. She thanks you for your kind support.

loans.use: to give her community better access to communication services by selling mobile airtime credits.

loans.name: Fadhili Kiliba Group

texts.fr:
A l'époque où Elisabeth était encore enfant, l'école était réservée uniquement aux garçons et le choix était clair pour les parents qui donnait une priorité au sexe masculin. Préparée pour être épouse et mère, la fille restait à la maison pour les travaux ménagers et accompagnait ses parents au champs. Devenue cultivatrice depuis son jeune âge, Elisabeth a continué à exercer cette activité après son mariage et jusqu'à présent. Avec une expérience de plus de 20 ans dans la riziculture, elle en connaît les bienfaits mais souhaite pouvoir améliorer la productivité de son champ grâce aux crédits qu'elle aura à bénéficier au PAIDEK. En résolvant son problème financier auquel elle est actuellement butée cela pourra l'aider à sortir sa famille dans cette situation de précarité.
Présidente du groupe FADHILI KILIBA, elle est habillée en robe noire et foulard rouge et tient dans l'une de mains un carnet.
texts.en: At the time when Elisabeth was still a child, school was reserved for boys and the choice was simple for parents who gave priority to the male sex. Girls stayed at home, preparing to be wives and mothers, doing the housework and accompanying their parents out to the fields. Elisabeth became a farmer at an early age and has continued to do this since she has been married. She has more than 20 years' experience of growing rice now and knows all the benefits but would like to be able to improve productivity in her field as a result of the loans she will have from PAIDEK. Resolving her current financial problems could help her family to survive this precarious situation. She is president of the Fadhili Kiliba group and is dressed in a black dress with a red scarf in the photo, holding a notebook in one hand.

loans.use: to cover hoeing and harvest costs as well as to buy fertilizers and phytosanitary products.

loans.name: Merrycris

texts.en:
Merrycris is from lopez Jaena, in the Philippines. She and her husband have agricultural land composed of coconut trees and earn a living through farming. They also cultivate rice near their home. 

To generate more income Merrycris decided to plant bananas, root crops and other commodities by inter-cropping. She makes it a point to have good land preparation so she will have maximum yield and a good income. 

She recently needed a loan from Paglaum MPC to finance farming activities such as clearing, digging holes and planting on her land. She wishes to sustain her business and to be able to supply more crops to the neighboring towns.

loans.use: to finance farming activities such as clearing, digging holes and planting on her land.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en: Delia, 47 years old, lives in Lopez Jaena with her husband and five children. Her husband is a construction worker. Unable to sustain the needs of the family with only her husband’s income, she has found ways to earn income through selling snacks and food. She began by selling a small amount of food dishes and snacks to their neighbors. She joined Paglaum Cooperative, which helped her capitalize on her sari-sari (small grocery) store in January of 2014. Now she is applying for an 8,000 PHP loan to buy merchandise for her sari-sari store. She hopes that her business will continue and someday become a mini-grocery.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Alondras Group

texts.es:
Durante la tarde los habitantes de cierta comunidad oaxaqueña se dedican a la pesca; ellos se adentran hasta el centro de la presa cuya desembocadura ha formado pequeñas islas. La más popular de ellas es la isla de las mujeres mazatecas, ya que cada ama de casa que habita allí conserva sus tradiciones, celebraciones y lengua. Por otra parte se dedican a la elaboración de bordados mazatecos hechos a mano. 
   En dicha comunidad se ha constituido un grupo llamado Alondras, ellos son: Minerva y Dulce quienes venden comida; María, postres y comida; Rosalia, pescado; Leonarda, dulces. Mientras que Julio tiene una carpintería y Jerónimo se dedica a la decoración y es coreógrafo. 
   Jerónimo es soltero y vive con sus padres a quienes apoya económicamente con los gastos de la casa. Alondra, como es mejor conocido, siente una gran pasión y gusto por el baile por lo que decidió convertirse en coreógrafo para XV años, clausuras escolares, bodas y para el carnaval de la comunidad. “Me encanta bailar, transmitir la alegría y enseñar a los niños, jóvenes y en ocasiones adultos a divertirse de manera sana”. Jerónimo espera acrecentar su actividad y compartir la manera de mantenerse en buena condición gracias al baile, para lograrlo desea dar clases de zumba a las personas de su comunidad. Él siempre dedica 5 horas diarias a practicar, eso le ha permitido gozar de buena salud y el resto del tiempo lo dedica a su segunda actividad.
   Para el servicio de decoración de espacios ha realizado su propio catálogo con diseños que él mismo adecuó para que a sus clientes les sea más fácil elegir lo que prefieren para su evento. El préstamo lo empleará en tela, alfileres, globos, naturaleza muerta y focos nuevos ya que las clausuras escolares se acercan y tiene demasiado trabajo “en temporada de graduaciones me ocupo seis horas diarias, pues enseño el vals a niños de preescolar, primaria y adolescentes de secundaria”.
   El grupo Alondras agradece la confianza que se les ha brindado para obtener un préstamo.

*En la fotografía se puede apreciar a los integrantes del grupo, Jerónimo es quien viste playera negra.
texts.en:
During the afternoon the inhabitants of one Oaxacan community is engaged in fishing; They go into the center of the dam whose mouth has formed small islands. The most area is the island of the Mazatec women, as every housewife who lives there preserves their traditions, celebrations and language. Moreover they engages in the development of Mazatec handmade embroidery.
   In this community a group called Larks has formed. The members are: Minerva and Dulce who sell food; Mary, desserts and food; Rosalia, fish; Leonarda, sweets. Julio has a carpentry business and Jerome has a business as a decorator and choreographer.
   Jerome is single and lives with his parents who financially support the household expenses. Alondra, as he is better known, has a passion and love for dancing so he decided to become a choreographer for quincineña celebrations, school festivities, weddings and community carnivals. "I love to dance, convey joy and teach children, youth and sometimes adults to have fun in a healthy way." Jerome expects to expand his business and help others stay in good shape through dance and reaching his goal by teaching Zumba people of his community. He spends 5 hours a day practicing, which has allowed him to be healthy and the rest of the time is dedicated to his second job.
   For decoration service he has made his own catalog with designs he adapted himself to his customers to make it easier to choose what they prefer for their event. The loan will be used to buy fabric, pins, balloons, artificial greenery and new lighting as end of school year approaches and he has too much work "during graduation season I work six hours, as I teach the waltz to preschool, primary and high school students. "
   The Larks group appreciates the trust that has been given them for a loan.

* In the picture you can see the members of the group, Jerome is wearing the black shirt.

loans.use: to buy fabric, pins, balloons, artificial greenery and new lighting

loans.name: Amigas Group

texts.es:
El fuerte lazo de amistad que mantienen las siete integrantes del grupo es lo que dio origen a su nombre: Amigas. Ellas son muy trabajadoras, responsables y comprometidas, todas son originarias de la misma comunidad donde la actividad principal es la pesca que se lleva a cabo en una presa. Los habitantes también se dedican al cultivo de caña de azúcar, maíz y frijol.
   Las Amigas y sus actividades son: Ana y Romualda quienes venden abarrotes; Yumeli, zapatos; Julieta, ropa; Yurixvy, refresco; Ana Cristal, bisutería y Guadalupe quien maneja un taxi.
   Doña Julia está casada con el señor Roberto con quien tiene cuatro hijos mayores de edad. Cuando su esposo estaba en Estados Unidos ella tuvo que ocuparse de tres de sus hijos ya que aún estudiaban. Su hermana la apoyó con un paquete de ropa americana para revender con lo que inició así su actividad y las ganancias obtenidas las reinvirtió en más ropa y cosméticos. 
   Al principio Julia solía recorrer las calles de la comunidad, mas hoy en día debido a su edad debe vender en el corredor de la casa de una sobrina, ahí exhibe la ropa para que el cliente elija libremente, además cuenta con un probador y espejo. La fortaleza de Doña Julia continúa pues actualmente ella es quien se hace cargo de un nieto. “Hace 6 años luché por mis hijos, ahora lucho por mí y por mi nieto” comenta decidida.
   Para Doña Julia el apoyo que su familia le ha brindado ha sido indispensable para salir adelante y se muestra agradecida por la gran familia que tiene. Esta vez el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de perfumes para dama y caballero.
   El grupo Amigas agradece la confianza brindada al otorgarles la posibilidad del préstamo para poder invertirlo en su actividad y con las ganancias ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.

*La fotografía fue tomada en el municipio donde viven las integrantes, doña Julia es quien viste falda color café.
texts.en:
The strong bond of friendship that the seven members of the group maintain is what gave rise to its name: Amigas (Friends). They are very hard-working, responsible, and committed. They all come from the same community, where the main activity is fishing, which is carried out on a dam. The inhabitants also make a living from cultivating sugar cane, corn, and beans.

The members of Las Amigas and their activities are: Ana and Romulada, who sell groceries; Yumeli, shoes; Julieta, clothing; Yurixvy, soft drinks; Ana Cristal, costume jewelry; and Guadalupe, who drives a taxi.

Julia is married to Roberto, with whom she has four adult children. When her husband was in the United States she had to take responsibility for three of her children since they were still studying. Her sister supported her with a packet of American clothing to resell with which she began her activity, and she reinvested the profits obtained in more clothing and cosmetics.

At first, Julia normally traversed the streets of the community. Nowadays, owing to her age, she has to make her sales out of the hallway of a niece’s home. She exhibits the clothing there so that the clientele can choose freely. Also, she has a changing room and a mirror. Julia’s strength continues; currently she is taking care of a grandchild. “6 years ago I struggled for my children; now I’m struggling for myself and for my grandchild,” she comments resolutely.

For Julia, the support that her family has provided her has been indispensable to succeed and expresses thanks for the great family that she has. This time, she will invest the loan in the purchase of perfumes for ladies and gentlemen.

*The photograph was taken in the municipality where the members live. Julia is the one who is wearing a brown skirt.

loans.use: to purchase perfumes for women and men.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is juggling a business and supervising the renovation of their home. 

Marilou hopes to live comfortably with a house with a durable ceiling and walls. Her loan of PHP 20,000 will help her to achieve this. 

She hopes to maintain her membership in good standing with a good repayment record.

loans.use: to renovate her house.

location.town: Plaridel - Cartagena Proper, Plaridel, Misamis Occ

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie is a strong-willed mother for her four children. She runs a retail business with variety of used clothing items. 

To fully expand and improve her project, she requested a loan. In the future, Virgie hopes to sustain her business and wants to renovate her house.

loans.use: to restock her retail business with various used clothing items.

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en: Ellen is 47 years old and lives in Macalibre Alto, Lopez Jaena. Ellen is married and she joined PMPC in order to access their programs and services. Recently, she has requested a loan in the amount of PHP 7,000 for additional working capital for her existing business to buy a variety of commodities and food products that she sells in the local community.

loans.use: to buy a variety of commodities and food products that she sells in the local community

loans.name: Los Canarios Group

texts.es:
Los integrantes del grupo Los Canarios viven en una bella comunidad mazahua donde se conserva la lengua materna, además es una región pintoresca, adornada por frondosos árboles. La calidez de sus habitantes es destacable, característica que los distingue de otras comunidades.
   Gran parte de la población se dedica a la cría de animales de granja como borregos, cerdos y vacas. Otra actividad importante es el cultivo de maíz, por ello cada año trabajan las milpas con dedicación para obtener las mejores cosechas.
   Doña Otilia es una persona muy agradable, siempre es un gusto platicar con ella, lo que la hace muy querida en su comunidad. Está casada con don Tomás y juntos formaron una familia con siete hijos, de los cuales ya sólo dos dependen de la pareja y uno continúa sus estudios.
   Otilia tiene diez años de experiencia en la venta de sombreros y gorras, recuerda que la idea surgió a partir de un viaje a la capital en donde vio un puesto de sombreros. Posteriormente compró algunos y los revendió con sus vecinas quienes compraron toda la mercancía. Ahora quiere hacer una mayor inversión en su negocio para satisfacer a sus clientes "actualmente también vendo en las plazas y en los tianguis de mi comunidad" comentó doña Otilia.
   Con el beneficio del préstamo comprará más sombreros, pues aunque reconoce que ya hay más competencia siempre obtiene buenas ventas gracias a la calidad. Con las ganancias apoya con los gastos del hogar y educación de su hijo lo cual es su prioridad ya que el muchacho quiere estudiar enfermería.
   Los demás integrantes del grupo son Anastacia, Lidia, Eusebia, Filogonio y Lourdes quienes invertirán en borregos; Andrés, en zapatos y Gilberto, en su taller mecánico.

*La fotografía fue tomada en las escaleras debajo del kiosco municipal, doña Otilia es quien viste suéter blanco*
texts.en:
The members of Los Canarios communal bank live in a beautiful Mazahua community where the native language is still spoken. It is also a picturesque area adorned by leafy trees. The warmth of its people is notable and is a characteristic that distinguishes it from other communities. Many of the people engage in raising farm animals such as sheep, pigs and cows. Another important activity is growing corn and every year they work the cornfields with dedication in order to obtain the best harvest.

Otilia is a very nice person with whom it is always a pleasure to have a conversation. This makes her beloved in her community. She is married to Tomas and together they have raised a family of seven children, of whom only two are now dependent upon their parents and one continues studying. 

Otilia has ten years of experience selling hats and caps and remembers that she got the idea when she took a trip to the capital and saw someone selling hats from a stand. She later bought some and resold them to her neighbors who bought them all up. Now she wants to make a bigger investment in her business in order to satisfy her customers.  "Currently I also sell in the plazas and in the markets in my neighborhood," Otilia states.

With the benefit of the loan, she will buy more hats. Although she recognizes that there is more competition now, she always has good sales because of the quality of her merchandise. With her earnings she is able to help with the household expenses and her son's education which is her priority because he wants to study nursing. 

The other members of the group are Anastacia, Lidia, Eusebia, Filogonio and Lourdes who will invest in sheep; Andres will invest in shoes; and Gilberto in his mechanics shop.

*The photo was taken on the steps beneath the town kiosk. Otilia is the one wearing a white sweater.

loans.use: to buy hats, caps, etc.

location.town: La Virgen del Centro, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Las Tres Cruces Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad de origen mazahua dentro del Estado de México se encuentra ubicado el grupo Las Tres Cruces. Las integrantes decidieron identificarse con ese nombre ya que cerca del lugar donde viven hay tres cruces que identifican la población. Además, justo al pie de las cruces es donde mes con mes, los habitantes se reúnen para llevar a cabo las fiestas patronales.
   El grupo de préstamo está integrado por mujeres trabajadoras, entregadas a su familia. Cada una de ellas tiene algún tipo de negocio que pretenden mejorar con el préstamo. Así, Carolina y Adelina invertirán en borregos; Erika, en bordados; María de los Ángeles y Marisol, en ropa. 
   Doña Martina siempre se muestra muy alegre, está casada con el señor Lorenzo quien trabaja en la construcción en la Ciudad de México. Son padres de cinco hijos aunque ya sólo una joven depende de ellos. 
   Martina solicita el préstamo para comprar más tela cuadrille, hilos, estambres, además de pollos y borregos. Durante diecisiete años se ha dedicado a la elaboración de servilletas, manteles, y otras piezas bordadas y también, a la crianza de pollos y borregos. Martina inició estas actividades porque quería colaborar con los gastos de su hogar y la educación de sus hijos. 
   Para ella, tener dos negocios no implica una dificultad pues atiende a los animales por la mañana, los saca a pastar al campo; al mediodía les vuelve a dedicar una hora para cambiarlos de lugar y volver a alimentarlos. Mientras que a la elaboración de bordados le dedica las horas que restan de su día. Martina invierte hasta 20 días para completar una pieza bordada. En ocasiones, las personas de su comunidad le hacen encargos de varios bordados para entregar como recuerdos en celebraciones, por ejemplo bautizos, primeras comuniones, confirmaciones y bodas.
   A Doña Martina no le preocupa la competencia porque ya tiene clientes seguros y siempre busca hacer su trabajo con la mejor calidad, lo que le ha ayudado a que las personas siempre la recomienden. Su sueño es seguir creciendo en sus negocios para apoyar a su esposo y mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda.

*La fotografía fue tomada en la plaza del kiosco municipal, doña Martina viste un suéter negro y una blusa blanca*
texts.en:
Martina is asking for a loan to buy more checked fabric, thread, worsted wool, chickens and sheep. For 17 years, she has worked making napkins, table cloths, and other embroidered items, as well as raising and fattening chickens and sheep. She started her activities because she wanted to help with the household expenses and her children's education expenses.
For Martina, it hasn't been difficult having two businesses because she cares for the animals in the morning, and takes them to graze in the pasture.   At midday she spends more time moving them to a different place and feeding them again.  Doing the embroidery is what she spends the rest of her time on every day. It can take her up to 20 days to finish a piece. 
At times, people from her community order different embroidered pieces to deliver for mementos of celebrations such as baptisms, first communions, confirmations, and weddings. 
Martina isn't worried about competition in her community because she already has regular customers and she always tries to do her work with the best quality so that they will keep recommending her. Her dream is to keep growing in her businesses to help with the household expenses and improve her home.

Note:  this photograph was taken in the pavilion of a  municipal plaza.  Martina is seen wearing a black sweater and a white blouse.

loans.use: to buy dressmaking supplies and also chicken and sheep

location.town: Guadalupe Cote, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Linderos Group

texts.es:
Doña Alicia es una mujer muy sonriente, su amabilidad y calidez humana la caracterizan dentro de su comunidad. Alicia está casada con el señor Juvenal quien trabaja en la Cuidad de México en la construcción de casas; tienen una familia muy unida compuesta por tres hijos, de los cuales, dos estudian la educación primaria. La comunidad donde vive la familia es de origen mazahua; es muy pacífica y la distinguen, además los paisajes de árboles frondosos y clima fresco. Para llegar a la casa de doña Alicia se debe atravesar varios cultivos de maíz. Desde lo alto de su vivienda se puede apreciar el paisaje que ofrece toda la comunidad. 
   Doña Ali, como la conocen las integrantes del grupo, inició con una tienda de abarrotes ya que donde vive no había ninguna persona que ofreciera el servicio. Comenzó vendiendo únicamente dulces y refrescos pero sus vecinos la animaron a vender otro tipo de productos; no obstante, al no contar con el capital necesario se acercó a VisionFund. "Fue una oportunidad muy buena para mí y para mi familia porque sabía que si mi negocio crecía, crecería también la calidad de vida de mis hijos" comentó entusiasmada.
   Afortunadamente el negocio es muy productivo y continúa sin ningún tipo de competencia cercana. Sin embargo, carece de vehículo para trasladar la mercancía por lo que le encantaría tener una camioneta y así dejar de pagar el servicio de transporte. Otro de sus sueños es poder mejorar su vivienda porque le hacen falta ventas y el aplanado de las de las paredes. Con el préstamo podrá comprar productos como pan, huevo, leche, refresco, productos enlatados, que son los productos de mayor demanda. 
   Las demás integrantes del grupo son María Guadalupe, Francisca, Leticia S., Virginia, Marcela, Paula, Leticia D. y Teresa quienes invertirán en comprar ganado ovino.

 *La fotografia fue tomada en la plaza del quiosco del municipio, Doña Ali es quien carga al bebé en la espalda (costumbre muy tradicional en la region) y viste suéter azul.
texts.en:
Doña Alicia is a woman with a big smile; and she is known within her community for her kindness and her humanity.  Alicia is married to Señor Juvenal, who works building houses in Mexico City. They have a very close family composed of three children, two of whom are studying in primary school. The community where the family lives is of Mazahua origin.  It is very peaceful, and known for its landscapes of leafy green trees and its cool climate. To get to Doña Alicia’s house you must cross several fields of corn, and from her home’s height, you can appreciate the landscape offered by the whole community.

Doña Ali, as she is known by the members of the group, started with a grocery store, as where she lives no one was offering this service. She started out selling only sweets and soft drinks, but her neighbors encouraged her to sell other types of products. But, as she didn’t have the necessary capital, she approached VisionFund. “It was a very good opportunity for me and for my family, because I knew that if my business grew, my family’s quality of life would also grow better”, she says enthusiastically.

Fortunately, the business is very productive and continues without any type of competition nearby. However, she lacks a vehicle for transporting the merchandise, so she would love to have a little truck, and thus stop paying for transport service.  Another of her dreams is to be able to improve her house, because it needs windows and stucco for the walls. With the loan, she will be able to purchase products such as bread, eggs, milk, soft drinks, and canned products, which are the products most in demand.

The other members of the group are María Guadalupe, Francisca, Leticia S., Virginia, Marcela, Paula, and Leticia D. and Teresa, who will purchase sheep. 

The photograph was taken in the plaza of the town pavilion. Doña Ali is the person carrying a baby on her back (a custom that is very traditional in the region) and wearing a blue sweater.

loans.use: to purchase grocery products such as bread, eggs, milk, etc.

location.town: San Miguel La Labor, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Grupo Evenecer Group

texts.es:
A los integrantes del Grupo Evenecer los une un lazo familiar, son personas muy trabajadoras que desempeñan el oficio de panaderos. El arte de hacer pan en su familia ha pasado de generación en generación. El nombre del grupo lo eligieron por su devoción, ya que significa “Dios está con nosotros”. La comunidad a la que pertenecen los integrantes se caracteriza por tener a los mejores panaderos de la región y por ser un lugar donde las personas aún conservan su lengua mazahua.
      Doña Esperanza tiene 25 años de experiencia en su actividad, sin embargo el camino no fue sencillo “Realmente fue muy difícil levantar el negocio, muchas veces tuve que privarme de ropa, zapatos entre otras necesidades básicas para poder tener el negocio” comentó con nostalgia. Inició vendiendo pan frío en ferias, fiestas, tianguis, prácticamente en cualquier lugar que le fuera posible. Durante 15 años continuó de esta manera, mas siempre había soñado con tener un puesto en dónde ofrecer pan de fiesta recién salido del horno. Gracias a su esfuerzo y ganancias pudo lograrlo y ahora se ha convertido en una de las mejores panaderas. 
   No obstante, otra de sus metas es establecer un local dentro de su casa para no tener que salir a recorrer las calles. Doña Esperanza piensa legar su negocio a sus hijos, tres de ellos ya dedican sus días a este oficio y cada uno de ellos tiene su negocio individual.
   Doña Esperanza está realmente contenta y agradecida con VisionFund por los préstamos obtenidos, con los que ha logrado ampliar negocio e incluso comprar un vehículo para trasladar equipo, insumos y producto. Ahora con esta nueva posibilidad de préstamo comprará harina, huevo, leche, azúcar, etc. ingredientes indispensables para dar continuidad a su producción.
   Los demás integrantes del grupo son Israel, Lizbeth, Rosendo, Ana Cristina quienes también invertirán en sus respectivas panaderías. 

* La fotografía fue tomada enfrente del palacio municipal, doña Esperanza es quien porta el mandil azul marino*
texts.en:
The members of the Group Evenecer unites under family ties.  They are very hardworking people who work as bakers.  The art of making bread in their family has been passed down generation after generation.  They picked the name of the group for their devotion, since it means "God is with us."  The community that the members belong to is characterized by having the best bakers in the region and for being a place where the people still speak in their Mazahua language.

Doña Esperanza has 25 years of experience in this job.  However, the path was not easy.  "It was really difficult to start a business.  Many times I had to deprive myself of clothing, shoes, among other basic needs to be able to have the business," she commented with nostalgia.  She began selling fried bread at carnivals, parties, street markets, practically anywhere she could.  For 15 years she continued in this way, but she has always dreamed of having a stall where she could offer bread for parties recently taken out of the oven.  Thanks to her hard work and earnings, she was able to succeed and now she has become one of the best bakers. 

Nevertheless, another goal of hers is to establish a place in her home to not have to go out and travel the streets.  Doña Esperanza plans on leaving the business to her children, three of whom already work daily in this job and each one has his individual business.  

Doña Esperanza is truly happy and grateful with VisionFund for the loans that they have obtained.  With them, she has been able to increase business and even buy a vehicle to transport the equipment, input, and product.  Now, with this new possible loan, she will buy flour, eggs, milk, sugar, etc. indispensable ingredients to continue her production.

The other members of the group are Israel, Lizbeth, Rosendo, and Ana Cristina, who will also invest in their respective bakeries.

*The photograph was taken in front of the municipal palace; doña Esperanza is the one wearing the Navy blue apron.*

loans.use: To buy flour, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Chicas Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
Chicas Emprendedoras es un grupo cuyo nombre describe a la perfección a sus integrantes ya que éstas siempre buscan el bienestar de su familia. Todas mantienen una relación de amistad y esto las ha llevado a solicitar un préstamo a VisionFund con el propósito de mejorar sus negocios.
   María Teresa es llamada Tere de cariño, es una mujer muy amable, prueba de ello: su eterna sonrisa. Otra característica que la distingue, es la entrega a su trabajo. Tere está cansada con Francisco y ahora tienen una linda familia con tres niños pequeños.
   Ella mantiene la misma actividad desde hace cinco años, se dedica a la elaboración de postres, panes y pasteles. Comenzó porque durante muchos años laboró en la Ciudad de México como empleada doméstica y sus misma jefas le enseñaban a elaborar todo tipo de postres. Actualmente ella vende de casa en casa y su delicioso sazón le ha permitido que tener pedidos especiales, por ejemplo su rico pan de naranja ahora famoso entre sus vecinas. Tere compartió emocionada una de sus mejores ventas “el 10 de mayo, día de las madres, me fue súper bien, mis ganancias fueron muy buenas y tuve muchos encargos de pasteles”.
   Con el préstamo podrá comprar ciertos moldes grandes que le hacen falta, harina, huevo, leche, también maíz, papel y leña porque además tiene una tortillería con su mamá Cecilia, integrante del grupo. Esa actividad complementaria va avanzando bien pues al día llegan a vender hasta 45 cuartillos de maíz (cada cuartillo equivale 1.5 kg). Uno de los sueños de Tere es abrir varias sucursales de tortillería en su comunidad para terminar de construir su y casa y mejorar su calidad de vida. 
   Las integrantes del grupo son Rachel quien invierte en trastes y colchas; Cecilia, en tortillería; Rufina, en su estética; Mónica, en frutas y verduras; Liliana, en colchas y Angélica, en zapatos y colchas.

*La fotografía fue tomada en la casa de Cecilia, en la imagen aparecen utensilios y algunas materias primas de Tere con las que elabora los postres, Tere viste sudadera blanca*
texts.en:
This group's name "Chicas Emprendedoras" ["Enterprising Girls"] perfectly describes its members, who work hard for the well-being of their families. The group members are all good friends, and they are requesting a loan from VisionFund to improve their businesses.

María Teresa is affectionately nicknamed 'Tere'. She's a kind woman, who is always smiling, and is also known for her dedication to her work. Tere is married to Francisco, and has a beautiful family with three young children. 

She has been making desserts, bread and cakes for the last five years. She worked as a maid in Mexico City for many years, and her employers taught her how to make all kinds of desserts. She sells her products from house to house, and, thanks to the delicious flavors, she often receives special requests, for example her famous orange bread, which is famous among her neighbors. Tere, visibly moved, describes one of her best sales days, recounting that "the 10th of May, Mother's Day, was a great day, I earned well, and I received lots of orders for cakes".

She is requesting a loan to buy large cake pans, flour, eggs and milk, as well as corn, paper and firewood for the tortilla business which she runs with her mother, Cecilia, who is also a member of the group. The tortilla business is doing very well, and they can sell as many as 45 cuartillos (a cuartillo is about 1.5kg) of corn in a day. One of Tere's dreams is to open several branches of the tortilla business in her district, and earn enough to finish building her house and improve her quality of life.

Other members of the group are: Rachel, who wants to invest in dishes and blankets; Cecilia, in her tortilla business; Rufina, in beauty products; Mónica, in fruit and vegetables; Liliana, in blankets, and Angélica, in shoes and blankets.

*The photo was taken in Cecilia's house. In the photo, you can see some of the utensils and ingredients that Tere uses for her desserts. Tere is wearing a white sweatshirt in the picture.

loans.use: to buy large pans, flour, eggs, milk, corn, paper and firewood.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.es:
Concepción vive en una comunidad mexiquense tranquila y rodeada de naturaleza, para llegar a su casa se tiene que caminar varios kilómetros. No obstante lo que hace especial el recorrido es que se puede apreciar el panorama de milpas de maíz, que representa una de las actividades más importantes de los habitantes de origen mazahua.
   Conchita, como le dicen de cariño en su comunidad, es una mujer emprendedora y llena de energía. Desde hace 21 años contrajo matrimonio con Carlos y juntos han formado una linda familia con cinco hijos, de los cuales dos estudian: uno en preescolar y otro en educación primaria.
    En su afán de ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y la educación de sus pequeños, Conchita decidió elaborar distintos bordados como manteles o servilletas. Después de terminados los vende entre sus vecinos y familiares, asimismo desde hace quince años comenzó a criar becerros. Ella misma refiere, “en mi comunidad los becerros crecen muy rápido porque se les puede dar de comer maíz, zacate y alimento de costal que se puede encontrar sin problemas aquí”. Adquiere sus animales desde pequeños o en algunos casos medianos para que crezcan en menor tiempo y pueda venderlos pronto.
   Con una nueva oportunidad de préstamo comprará dos becerros y alimento suficiente, para ello siempre está al pendiente de que sus proveedores le entreguen la mejor calidad pues eso se refleja en su producto. Del mismo modo Doña Conchita siempre busca al mejor comprador. Una de sus metas es mejorar el negocio y tener por lo menos tres animales al mismo tiempo.

*La fotografía fue tomada fuera de su casa y muestra algunos de los bordados que ella misma confecciona*
texts.en:
Concpecion lives in a traquil community in Mexico surrounded by nature. One must walk many kilometers to get to her house. Still, during the trip to her house one can appreciate the special panorama of cornfields, which represent one of the most important commercial activities for the inhabitants of Mazahua origin. 

Conchita, as her community calls her with affection, is an entrepreneurial woman and is full of energy. She has been married to Carlos for 21 years. Together they formed a beautiful family of five children, of which two go to school: one in preschool and the other in primary school. In her eagerness to help her spouse with the living and education expenses, Conchita decided to make different embroidery such as tablecloth and handkerchief. After finishing the products, she sells them to her neighbors and family members. 

In the same way, since 15 years ago she started to raise calves. She herself comments, "in my community, the calves grow very fast because you can feed them with corn, grass, and sacked pastures which you can find around here with no problem."  She acquires her animals when they are small, or in some cases, when they are half-grown, so that they can grow within less time and she can sell them sooner. 

With the new opportunity of the loan, she will buy two calves and sufficient food. For this, she is always waiting on her supplier to find her the best quality product. In the same manner, Conchita always looks for the best buyer. One of her goals is to improve the business and have at least three animals at the same time. 

*The photograph was taken outside of her house and shows some of the embroidery that she herself makes*

loans.use: to purchase calves and pasture

location.town: El Valerio, San Jose del Rincon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more boxes of beer in order to increase the stock of her business

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is a 55-year-old married woman with seven children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Merlita has a cafeteria business in the Philippines. Merlita requested a PHP 9,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy additional coffee, sugar and milk.

Merlita has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Merlita would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional coffee, sugar, and milk.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Aurora works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from direct selling Avon products. Aurora is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials for the maintenance of her fishing business.

Aurora has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for the maintenance of her business

loans.name: Arlen

texts.en: Arlen, 40, is a married woman with nine children, seven of whom are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. For five years, Arlen has been buying and selling vegetables and root-crops in the Philippines. Arlen requested a 15,000 PHP loan through Kiva's partner, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, to purchase more vegetables and root-crops to sell. In the future, Arlen would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables and root-crops to sell

loans.name: Jerramae

texts.en:
Jerramae is a married woman with three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Jerramae is 29 years old and has two children who are in school.

Jerramae has a general store business in the Philippines. Jerramae requested a PHP 7,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

Jerramae has been in this business for two years. In the future, Jerramae would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en: Dolores is 65 years old, married, with five children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. For ten years, Dolores has been manufacturing hollow, construction blocks in the Philippines. Dolores requested a 12,000 PHP loan through Kiva's partner, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, to buy additional sand, gravel and cement for business. In the future, Dolores would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional sand, gravel and cement for manufacturing blocks.

loans.name: Bellarosa

texts.en:
Bellarosa is 65 years old, and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, etc. 

Bellarosa has borrowed and paid 35 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from farming rice.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, personal care products, etc.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 27 years old and married with two children.

Gina works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 40,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional products to sell such as canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, coffee, etc.

Gina has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from buying and selling fish.

She successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Gina aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell such as canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, coffee, etc.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 38 years old and married with three children.  With two children in school, Marilyn works very hard to provide for them.

Marilyn runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell.

Marilyn has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap and other groceries. 

In the future Marilyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of groceries to sell

loans.name: Caryl

texts.en:
Caryl is 35 years old and has three children. Caryl is married and has three children who are in school.

Caryl is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Caryl requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase feeds, vitamins and other supplies for her pigs.

Caryl has been in pig fattening for 6 years now, and has borrowed 5 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Caryl would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase feeds, vitamins and other supplies for her pigs.

loans.name: Cesariana

texts.en:
Cesariana works hard to support her family. Cesariana is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Cesariana requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional fishing nets for her fishing business.

Cesariana has been in this business for 10 years now.

Cesariana would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing nets for her fishing business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 52 years old and married with seven children.

She earns a living by having a pig fattening business in the Philippines. Elizabeth is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Elizabeth has been in pig fattening for 20 years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with one child.

She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 26,000 through NWTF in order to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her livestock.

She supplements this income with earnings from her general store business.

Mary Grace dreams that one day, she will be able to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her livestock.

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly is 57 years old and married with ten children.

She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. Beverly is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her livestock.

Beverly has been raising livestock for 15 years and also earns additional income from farming sugarcane.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her livestock.

loans.name: Fatkhidin

texts.ru: Фатхидин, 52 года, женат, отец 2 детей. У него среднее образование, на протяжении 34 лет занимается полеводством. На сегодняшний день, в хозяйстве Фатхидина имеется 1,50 Га арендованной земли выращивает кукурузу и капусту для реализации оптовым покупателям. Фатхидин хочет развить свой бизнес, в связи с этим он обратился в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом, в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку семян, удобрений, оплату полива поля и на прочие расходы по выращиванию органических овощей. На доходы от кредита он хочет увеличить свой бизнес и женить сыновей.
texts.en:
Fatkhidin is 52 and married with two children. He has a high school education and has been working in agriculture for 34 years. He currently as 1.5 hectares of rented land where he grows corn and cabbage for sale to wholesale buyers. 

Fatkhidin wants to develop his business and has therefore approached Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase seeds and fertilizer and to pay for someone to irrigate his field so that he can grow organic vegetables. He wants to use profits from the loan to further improve his business and to pay for his sons' weddings.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer and to pay for irrigation of his field in order to grow organic vegetables

loans.name: Erica

texts.en:
Erica is 34 years old and married with six children, two of whom are in school. Erica works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a business buying and selling gasoline in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional containers of gasoline to sell.

Erica has been in this business for 10 years.

In the future Erica would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional containers of gasoline to sell.

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.en:
Gregorio is an artisan from Nicaragua who specializes in ceramic archaeological replicas. He would like to invest in a bulk purchase of paint.

He has been selling his crafts through Novica, an e-commerce website for artisans, since 2013. This is his story:

"Today I am a master artisan. But to be able to craft archaeological replicas, I had to work very hard. I was born on September 3, 1949 in San Juan de Oriente, Nicaragua. I work in ceramics and my specialty is pre-Hispanic replicas. My adventure in art began when I was just a boy and would watch my parents work. I always liked the original and beautiful pieces our ancestors left for us. So I learned ceramic work from my father and with a teacher in the city of Masaya. Today, I work alone with no assistants or students. I consider myself a respectable person, friendly and, above all, responsible. This wasn't always the case. As a youth, I was an alcoholic; I was irresponsible at work and at home. Thank God, my life changed in 1988 when I became a Christian and stopped drinking. After that, I was able to dedicate myself to my true calling — my art.

"From Nicaragua I send you my gratitude for the support and faith you are placing in me by way of this microcredit. Many thanks, my friends!"

Use this link to view Gregorio's ceramic archaeological replicas on the Novica site: http://www.novica.com/artistdetail/?faid=9126

loans.use: to invest in a bulk purchase of paint

loans.name: Marygen

texts.en:
Marygen works raising swine in Unidos, Plaridel, Philippines. This is how she makes a living and supports her family. Marygen’s lowest point was when she didn't have enough capital for her business. 

When she joined PMPC, she was truly grateful to access credit to support her business. Marygen takes her PMPC membership as seriously as she does her hog-raising business. She wants to maintain her membership in good standing so she can always be eligible for any financing needs. 

Marygen is requesting a 6,000 PHP loan to purchase bags of feeds and animal vitamins for her piglets.  Marygen hopes to save enough to build a concrete pig pen to improve sanitation and care for the environment.

loans.use: to purchase bags of feeds and animal vitamins for her piglets.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en: Lorena has always dreamed of opening and managing her own retail store to support her needs. Lorena is married and lives in Plaridel, in the Philippines. She applied for a loan to restock her store with various commodities and other merchandise. She is now on her way to repaying the loan with her new profits and supporting her children.

loans.use: to restock her store with various commodities and other merchandise

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is a hardworking mother from Balanlinao, Plaridel. She is 47 years old and has a small business. Elvira and her husband have joined forces to put up their own junk store. 

When Elvira  started the business, she thought that the secret of buying and selling scrap materials was to be able to identify the type of scrap that she would sell. When it comes to metals, Elvira knows how she could double her income. She also knew the use of rusty tin cans, cooper, broken steel, and plastics. They put together broken appliances and salvaged motors of cars, everything that could still be of use, and they earn from it. 

Elvira has signed her membership with the cooperative to gain access to insurances and credit. She applied for a loan to purchase additional inventory to be used as working capital. Elvira hopes to succeed in this business so she can continuously provide for her family. 

In the future, she dreams of buying land to have a large space for her business and a hauling truck to do her deliveries.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory to be used as working capital.

loans.name: Lisa

texts.en:
Lisa is 32 years old, married, and a resident of Upper Bunawan, Philippines. Her husband is a tricycle driver. They have two children, both of whom are in school.  Starting with capitalization of 3,000 PHP, she opened a sari-sari (general store) and was able to expand it with the help of Paglaum Cooperative. Aside from financial assistance, she was able to generate savings and enjoys the benefit given by the co-op. She became a member in April 2012 and has taken out three loans. 

Now she is applying for 7,000 PHP to buy additional stocks for her sari-sari store, particularly basic commodities.  In the future, she wants to own a mini-mart someday, and will be fully satisfied if she sees her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to restock her grocery store

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria is from Magcamiguing, Calamba, Misamis Occidental, Philippines.  She is married and bravely raising three children.  PMPC supported her by providing the capital to start her pig-raising business. She sold one pig at a time, helping the family survive. She gives her best efforts to produce good pigs, in order to sell them continuously. 

Gregoria is now trying to expand her pig business and has also decided to venture into a little restaurant. She presented her project proposal to Paglaum MPC to finance the project and has applied for a loan of PHP 10,000.  She is thankful to Paglaum MPC for financing her capital needs. In addition, she wanted her business to be well known and to build a good business management for her loyal customers.  With her extra income, she wishes to send all her children to school so they may have stable careers.

loans.use: to purchase  feeds

loans.name: Carmencita

texts.en:
Carmencita works hard to support her family. Carmencita is married and has a business buying and selling rice grains in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice grains to sell.

Carmencita has been in this business for 10 years now.

In the future, Carmencita would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice grains to sell.

loans.name: Reynalyn

texts.en:
Reynalyn is a 43-year-old married woman with five children, four of whom are still in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur.

Reynalyn has a business farming mango fruits in the Philippines. Reynalyn requested a PHP 8,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fertilizers, seeds and other farm supplies.

Reynalyn has been in this business for three years. She would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seeds and other farm supplies

loans.name: Arjean

texts.en:
Arjean is 49 years old and married with ten children. With five children currently in school, Arjean works very hard to provide for them.

Arjean runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks to sell in her general store.

Arjean has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items, such as canned goods, noodles, softdrinks, detergent soap, coffee, etc.

In the future, Arjean would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is 65 years old and married with nine children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.
